channel.title: NPR Morning Edition
channel.description: Morning Edition takes listeners around the country and the world with multi-faceted stories and commentaries every weekday. Hosts Steve Inskeep, Leila Fadel, Michel Martin and A Mart√≠nez bring you the latest breaking news and features to prepare you for the day.

item.title: Senate Republicans stall on Trump's spending package due to proposed Medicaid cuts
item.description: Senate Republicans have hit a roadblock in their quest to pass President Trump's sweeping domestic agenda by July 4.

item.title: He sued for marriage equality and won. 10 years later, he fears for LGBTQ+ rights
item.description: Jim Obergefell, plaintiff in the landmark Supreme Court case that legalized gay marriage in all 50 states, reflects on the decision 10 years later and the LGBTQ community's current civil rights fight.

item.title: Morning news brief
item.description: President Trump is back after a NATO summit in the Netherlands, what's next for Kilmar Abrego Garcia? The man who was wrongly deported to El Salvador, Senate Republicans rush to pass President Trump's signature policy bill.

item.title: Trump remains confident on damage U.S. strikes caused to Iran's nuclear sites
item.description: It's not yet clear to what extent U.S. airstrikes damaged Iran's nuclear sites, but President Trump and his cabinet are adamant the nuclear program has been set back by years.

item.title: John Bolton on intelligence assessments of U.S. strikes in Iran
item.description: NPR's Steve Inskeep talks with John Bolton, a national security advisor in President Trump's first term, about U.S. strikes on Iran and differing assessments of their success.

item.title: Senate Republicans rush to pass President Trump's signature policy bill
item.description: Senate Republicans are racing to pass President Trump's signature policy bill by a self-imposed July 4 deadline. They've hit some roadblocks, especially around funding for rural hospitals.

item.title: A new documentary tells the story of journalist Barbara Walters
item.description: A new documentary profiles journalist Barbara Walters, who fought sexist bullies throughout her career and still landed the biggest interviews. NPR's Michel Martin talks with director Jackie Jesko.

item.title: Here's how Zohran Mamdani rose to top of New York City's Democratic mayoral primary
item.description: How did a little known assemblyman become the presumptive Democratic nominee for mayor of New York City? NPR's A Martinez talks to Bob Hardt, political director of the NY1 news channel.

item.title: Preparing for the next heat wave
item.description: Summer in the Eastern half of the U.S kicked off with a massive heat wave, and the summer season is only just beginning. So how should you prepare your home and community for the next big heat wave?

item.title: Sean Combs' trial closing arguments set to begin
item.description: After six weeks of witnesses for the prosecution, Sean Combs' defense team rested after only 30 minutes Tuesday. Thursday, the final stage of Combs' trial begins.
